number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 20, 2014
												Opposing Force was the only expansion pack to Half-Life that was really crtically acclaimed, and there's a good reason for that. To get this out of the way: this is a full game, not a short ripoff, and it remains Gearbox's best game to date in my opinion. Not only does it rival the original game, it remains a strong candidate for the best Half-Life game ever made. It's hard to believe that typically with an expansion pack, and the fact that was developed by another team just makes it even more unfathomable. However, Opposing Force gets everything right with Half-Life. Usually expansion packs don't end up being too special. They often do little else than add more content to a pre-existing game. Stand-alone expansions tend to fare better. Other examples of this type besides Opposing Force include Halo 3: ODST and Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon. Opposing Force doesn't screw up anything. The puzzle solving elements are still great. The platforming elements are still great. What it ultimately improves on besides just the visuals, and this is the main reason why it's so great, is combat and pacing. All of the new weapons are fun to use. There is not a single moment in this game that lacks tension or feels off, and in the end although it stands on its own it gets tied together with Half-Life very cohesively. This is what an expansion pack should be in a perfect world: something that goes beyond what it's expanding upon. And although most don't, this is an exception.

content:
ber 4, 2015
												Here's my review for Half-Life: Opposing Force. 1st (standalone) expansion to Half-Life.Shall we began.GameplayIt's mostly same as it was in half-life 1 but improved as well alot more variety between weapon's then the original. Many  puzzling element's here and between. quick thinking required. and did i mention that you can shoot whoever you want? Ya you can do that it shoot the scientist's. shoot your fellow marines's. shoot that guard.GraphicsI can safely say best for it's time, Still very playable till now while other game's for it's time aren't. Only few graphical option's resolution and only a few bit more. But come on guy's it was 1999 okay.StoryIt take's in the same place (black mesa) but this time around you aren't a scientist no no no this time you are soldier hell ya baby. Joke's aside it's just great and put's you in the perspective of  Adrian Shephard,  U.S. Marine Corporal. You are sent to black mesa with your fellow marine's by the goverment to eliminate all threat's and silence the facility . The game occurs  after the incident  has already happend and you also get to see more off what happen's when the whole facility is destoryed. And no cut scenes here between event's same as the original half-life.SoundtrackWell there aren't many and no music in the menu as well. But still there are some and they are good.AiNot much to say here. Mostly same as it was in the original half-life which was pretty good so mostly it's the same here.Amount of play timeMore than 5 hour's. Very significant for a (standalone) expansion and the price alone.ConlusionSurely i fully reccomend you buy this gem if you are into half-life at all. For the price being only $4.99 dollar's i'd say get it.A worthy (standalone) expansion to the half life universe. Same puzzling element's with a different perspective , a variety of new mechanincs and weapon's.===================================================================Click me and follow us as Curator

												For a game made during the first stage of Valve's series, it holds up fine, and fits in with the rest of the other half lives made during this time (Half life, and Half life Blue Shift) I would recommend you buy the "Half life complete" Pack, if you want all of 'em, you'll save money.That's not to say this doesn't work on its own, it's able to get into interesting gameplay, it's just better when you have the rest of the games made during this time period (Said games I already mentioned) it's able to give you a plot you can follow, and a training mode that, well, actually trains you for the game.In all, the graphics are the same as the other half lives released, and the gameplay is too, (Modified a tad) I recommend it to those who enjoy all of the other games in the half life saga (NOT counting Deathmatch) as it focuses on story as much as gameplay and fighting. If you enjoyed half life 1, or half life blue shift, this should fit right into the spirit of its game-sibilings.

content:
, 2016
												Half Life Opposing Force is a 1999 Expansion of Valve's Half Life, In this "Retelling" of the infamous Black Mesa incident a manmade catastrophe that took place in some vague timespan between 2000 to 2009 AD and would ultimately pave the way for Earth's invasion by the Universal Union or "Combine"  during the seven hour war mentioned in Half Life 2. You play the game via the eye's of one Corporal Adrian Shephard a member of an fictional special forces unit within the United States military. The game starts with you and your "stars n stripes" squadmates already in the air over the desert surrounding Black Mesa debating what the purpose of their deployment is only to be shot down by alien aircraft. You wake up in an infirmary a few hours later to learn that the military incursion as seen towards the second "Half" of Half Life was failing and the high brass has ordered all personell to abandon the base. You make your way to the evacuation sight only to be stopped by the nefarious "Gman" who sees to it that you do not leave the base with your fellow soldiers. As the game continues on you encounter another military unit however this one unlike your fellow HECU marines are hostile. These are the "Black Ops" as their name suggests they are a Black Operations unit sent in to finish the job the HECU failed to do which was to contain the base by "Any means possible" in this case the Black Ops have brought along a nuclear bomb  to destroy the compound and anything in it. Aside from the Black Ops theres also the "Race X" aliens a new group of hostille species tunneling their way to our lovely Earth in the "Last hours" of the resonance cascade. At the climax of the game you battle the Race X's "Biggest and baddest" member the "Gene worm" a gigantic monstrosity that according to the official Prima guide was sent to "Terraform" Earth hoewever you manage to defeat this thing before it can do its thing it exploding in a burst of portal energy similar to the boss fight of the first game. You awaken on a V-22 with the gman who promptly tells you that you have seen to much and you will be "detained" until further notice. Adrian Shephard has yet to show his face since his 1999 debut in the series and due to Valve's more recent titles suchas Team Fortress 2 Dota 2 and CS:GO it is unlikely he or "Any" of the actual Half Life cast will be shown in a future title. overall this game is one of my favorites in this series. My only wish is that gearbox had made more of these expansions aside this Blue Shift and the PS2 expansion "Decay" I give it an 9.5/10

content:
5, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force -This game is an expansion of the original Half-Life. Its content will amount to, or at least in my experience, about half (punny) the play-time of Half-Life. It follows a different character, from, you guessed it, the opposing force. Going into this expansion I didn't think it would be at long as it was. So, it tended to drag on a bit around the middle. The gameplay is the same as Half-Life, but you get more weapons and other items. I had tons of fun with this expansion. If you are going to play Half-Life, I think you need to play this expansion, and the next (Blue Shift).I had one big problem at the end of the game, though. From what I hear, it's a pretty common glitch, but I had just beaten the final boss. Instead of fading away (like it should), it disappeared, and I was left wandering around, wondering what to do. You are supposed to be transported to the final scene of the game, but that didn't happen for me. Not sure if it was my version, or my platform or what. Thanks to the Steam ommunity I found a code to put into the console that sends you to the coorrect scene. :DAnyway, one big glitch near the end aside, this is a great expansion and worth the money (even more so if on sale). the story is interesting, and Half-Life fans will really enjoy it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 19, 2016
												Now it is time to review the next installment of the crowbar simulator, the 1999 version... Wait... There is no crowbar in this game? Then how can it be the next installment of the world's most famous crowbar simulator??!! no it must be the wrong game... No you say? The crowbar is replaced with a Pipe Wrench and a combat knife? that is just great, it is already going to be my favourite game of all time *thick sarcasm*Well let's jam!//I have to say that I have played Blue shift, in my opinion when it comes to new content and so on, Opposing force is way too superior compared to blueshift//Half-life: opposing forces is the first expansion of the original game which "supposedly" flips the game upside down. Well let just be honest, this expansion is very much like the original half-life just without any crowbar and other weapons like the hivegun, some new weapons, new monsters and probably lacking some bits compared to the original game. But is it still fun? I would say yes :) Even though this one probably misses some more plot compared to half-life(Which already had a little plot) then it would  probably still satisfy your craving when finishing the original one.This game is only recommend if!- IF YOU HAVE PLAYED THROUGH THE ORIGINAL HALF-LIFE'S SINGLEPLAYER- You do not mind an old game with old "ugly" grafic, glitches and somewhat buggy AI.- If you love the half-life franchies and want to know more because this one gives some more hints to the original game.- you like a FPS game with some puzzle elements(just like the original game this one does not give you the glues straight ahead when it comes to the "puzzles" and the plot itself)The killers of the game.- The plot itself was more lacking than the original and with lesser hints of what is going on like what is the x-race and so on.- Even though I loved some of the new weapons I must say that the M249 SAW was way!!!! too!!! powerful. Either they should have provided with less ammo or something else  because even on hard difficulty it was way too easy with this weapon.- NO CROWBAR!!!- The game just like the original is filled with glitches here and there where you can get stuck weird places especially loading scenes.- The AI is not that great, still gives some challenge, but often you can sneak kill them.The Sunshines of the game- IT IS HALFLIFE...- Some of the new weapons were quite interesting especially the living ones :3 so kawaii!- It gives more interesting details about the g-man and there are some quite interesting encounters - Some quite interesting new creatures compared to the original one.- The game is really good to make a real connection to the original one, you even get to see Morgan Freeman. :)The game itself did not bring that much new to the table, yes some new monsters, new weapons, soldiers which you can "control", use and loot when you have led them to their death :P. But the game seemed to be too easy and missing more to the story line throughout the gameplay.But in the end it was still fun to play and totally worth it when you meet G-man and get more hints and details about the mystery of the half-life franchies.But if you are not a really great fan of half-life and old FPS games then pass on.

content:
, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force was a surprising adventure for me. Having played and fallen in love with the rest of the franchise almost immediately, I had never gone into a Half-Life game with an air of skepticism. And here's what I think (I'll keep it quick to avoid TL;DR's):For anyone familiar with Half-Life, the gameplay is similarly fast-paced and exciting. However, I was impressed with the addition of new mechanics that made the game an entirely different experience. This expansion of the Half-Life universe boasts new enemies, environments, and TONS of weapons. It is shorter than Half-Life, but a lot is crammed into the time that you get. Playing as HECU Grunt Adrian Shepherd is a fresh and different experience from Half-Life. However, I do have one minor caution for anyone new to the series: This game is pretty difficult. The same could be said of Half-Life 1, considering they are both older games, but Opposing Force has some moments where things may take a dip into the frustrating part of the spectrum. So quicksave a lot, newbies.

content:
ber 12, 2012
												This was my first Half-Life game I ever owned and we're still on pretty good terms. In this game you play as Corporal Adrian German Shepherd Dog, who is a 22 year-old US Marine ready to get out there and kick some tail. With a training camp that could've ended up like the beginning of Stanley Kubrick's Full Metal Jacket, you instead prep up for an on-the-double military response call, only to be attacked by aliens on the way in, wiping out your platoon in the war zone that is the Black Mesa science facility. The mission is called off, and the US Marines are left to survive on their own. It's up to Adrian to survive against lots of spooky aliens and make his mark as a young, out-standing American citizen while escaping Black Mesa, using cool alien bio-weapons or sciencey gizmos that make you feel like the coolest kid on this side of the black stump!I love every Half-Life game, but something about this one sticks out to me a lot!

content:
er 28, 2015
												I haven't expected a lot new things from this expansion. Just additional hours of duct crawling and shooting.It is true at first. You just get climbable ropes, new type of helpers and guns.However as the story unfolds you really appreciate the "second view" thing, and I'm not talking only about revisiting old locations and Gordon Freeman appearances. I don't want to reveal too much but let's just say playing Opposing Force you suddenly realize from where some Half Life 2 and even Portal things came from. I haven't expected the story to be so much related to previous and future Half Life games because the development was outsourced to Gearbox Software   (Borderlands series).Corporal Shephard rather fights than brains his way through obstacles so the arsenal is pushed to the limit, both conventional and weird weapons. Flashlight is replaced with night vision goggles. This allows to keep fighting in pitch black areas. So it is still the same 'ol Black Mesa facility environment, but minor changes alters the gameplay enough to give it new feel. Opposing Force is a very pleasant conclusion to the original Half Life story.

content:
6, 2013
												This is a damn classic. It's difficult at times, but also gives you a unique feeling of lonely desperation that really works in the Half-Life setting; not to mention Half-Life's great sense of pacing is still present. Plus, the M249 SAW is awesome. (Although technically it's sort of a cross between the M249 and M60.)You play as one of the Marines who were sent to Black Mesa in the original game to kill aliens and silence (read: also kill) any survivors. Your mission doesn't exactly go as planned, though, and you soon find yourself as just one combatant in a conflict that gets nastier by the minute.There is working multiplayer with some servers up, and surprisingly enough new levels seem to have been added in addition to the original ones. All but one are either free-for-all deathmatch or team-based CTF. There is one team-based control point-style map. Aside from a snazzy new HUD, and some great new weapons & areas of Black Mesa to explore, you also have the ability to lead and command small groups of fellow soldiers. The AI can get a bit spotty, but this game is more than 13 years old. If you liked Half-Life, you'll like this too.They relatively recently patched in the original music that was composed for this game. You can download it separetely from this website[p-l-m.blogspot.com]. I'd say it's pretty good, and fits the character of the game.If you liked the original Half-Life, you should probably get this.

content:
, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing Force was a surprising adventure for me. Having played and fallen in love with the rest of the franchise almost immediately, I had never gone into a Half-Life game with an air of skepticism. And here's what I think (I'll keep it quick to avoid TL;DR's):For anyone familiar with Half-Life, the gameplay is similarly fast-paced and exciting. However, I was impressed with the addition of new mechanics that made the game an entirely different experience. This expansion of the Half-Life universe boasts new enemies, environments, and TONS of weapons. It is shorter than Half-Life, but a lot is crammed into the time that you get. Playing as HECU Grunt Adrian Shepherd is a fresh and different experience from Half-Life. However, I do have one minor caution for anyone new to the series: This game is pretty difficult. The same could be said of Half-Life 1, considering they are both older games, but Opposing Force has some moments where things may take a dip into the frustrating part of the spectrum. So quicksave a lot, newbies.

content:
r 14, 2013
												The first expansion for Half-Life, which is also it's best in my opinion.Challenging while retaining the spirit of Half-Life. The Soundtrack is also ambient and hectic.Played from the perspective of Adrian Sheapard, part of the military team sent to deal with the Black Mesa incident, you get to fight the Xen aliens, but also a mysterious race of aliens known as X. The game adds a few new weapons, new monsters, and the level design is damn good.The soundtrack is one of the best of the Half-Life 1 era games. Although Blue Shift uses the same soundtrack as Op4, Chris Jenson brings alot to the table. It easily matches Kelly Baileys original score.Opposing Force is the best expansion for Half-Life. It's pretty lengthy, stretching over 9 hours. Blue Shift is also good, but the new weapons and monsters aren't there, and the length is considerablly shorter due to Barney's story. The Half-Life series is not complete without these expansions.

content:
r 17, 2016
												I first played this when it came out in the Half-Life Platinum Bundle in stores, and at the time it was most likely the best game out there. Even now, it stands out as having some of the most memorable AI, interesting mechanics, and diverse weapons of any game I have ever seen. If you enjoyed Half-Life or any of it's other Gold-Source offshoots, you will like Opposing Force. Opposing force puts the player character into the Black Mesa incident much later than all other games in the series, and keeps the player there far after every other character's story has ended. One thing that sets this game far from other titles in the series is its difficulty. There are times when playing on hard that the AI for alien creatures and Black Ops teams seems to be almost mockingly hard. Even though they rely heavily on scripted paths and arenas, the Black Ops teams surpass what any enemy in the rest of the series can do, providing long fights that force the player to both act quickly and prepare for the multitude of tricks the enemy can pull at will.The weapons in this game were also an enjoyable departure from Half-Life, and may even outshine the innovative gravity gun from the sequels. Opposing Force arms players with many alien weapons, most notably, the embryo of one of the game's most memorable alien enemies. It also adds a handheld barnacle which, while ridiculous, is used as a grappling hook very similar to the recently added Team Fortress 2 grapple. The dislocator, although impractical as a weapon outside of emergencies, is a very interesting idea for a weapon, as it allows limited travel between Earth and Xen. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who enjoys speedrunning, the original Half-Life series, hard games, or doesn't mind trying older titles.

content:
30, 2015
												Half-Life: Opposing ForceThe Lambda incident through the eyes of the enemy Half-life: Opposing Force, developed by Gearbox and released in 1999, is an expansion pack for Valves critically acclaimed fps, Half-Life. With new weapons, aliens and gameplay Opposing Force, although not as good as its older sister, is a short and fun game to play after you’ve finished the original Half-Life.After a Resonance Cascade occurs ripping holes in dimensional space allowing aliens to pass through to earth, Corporal Adrian Shepard, a U.S. marine in the Hazardous Environment Combat Unit, and his team are sent to neutralize the situation by exterminating all life forms in the facility. This Resonance Cascade has also caught the attention of another alien species, Race X, who decided to conquer humanity and claim Earth as their own. This game is not essential to the Half-Life story line, however if you’re a big fan of the original game and are interested to see the Black Mesa incident through the eyes of the enemy, then this is a game worth playing. There are also many references to the first game and even a Gordon Freeman cameo.One feature which makes this game a great expansion pack for Half-Life is the fact that Gearbox introduced new enemies and weapons. If not for these aspects this expansion pack would be nowhere near as good as it is. My personal favourite weapon was the Barnacle Grapple which allowed you to latch onto organic matter and go flying towards it. There is also a Displacer Cannon which can beam you to Xen and back or obliterate other enemies no matter how large. The gameplay in general is the same as Half-Life with lots of platforming, puzzles and large battles against lots of enemies. You can even get help from other soldiers to heal you, break down doors or kill other enemies. The Graphics in Opposing Force are dated and nowhere near as good as those in Half-Life: Source, I wouldn’t recommend this game for people who cringe at bad graphics. The level design in Opposing Force, like its predecessor, is well thought out and goes well with the platforming, with lots of optional areas to explore.Overall this was a solid game from start to finish, however I would only recommend this game to those who loved Half-Life. The level design was great and the gameplay was fun with new weapons and enemies, however the graphics, for some people, may distract from this. Unfortunately there were no new “stand out” soundtracks in this game. Those from Half-Life were recycled.7.5/10

												This is possibly one of the easiest games to either recommend or not recommend - it is more Half-Life. If you enjoyed Half-Life, you should get this game. If you did not enjoy Half-Life, you should not. If you have not played Half-Life, you should get and play that game first.Simple as that.As for the game itself, this is the greater of the two Half-Life expansion packs. It's a somewhat short side story to the original Half-Life, following the story of one of the marines who is sent in to the Black Mesa facility after everything goes to hell...err....Xen. After the initial task goes awry, he's tasked with helping to eliminate the aliens. It's a great little expansion, if a bit short, and adds new weapon types, new auxiliary features to the interface, new enemies, you get the idea. Fantastic addition to the franchise mythos.

content:
y 27, 2016
												The main thing you need to know about this game is that it's not a simple retelling of the Half-Life chapters from the military perspective. Opposing Force is a great expansion pack which features new parts of Black Mesa Research Facility, new awesome weapons, new mysterious enemy called Race X and of course its own story that goes parallel to the events of the original Half-Life. On the other hand the game suffers from various glitches, the most famous being the Desert Eagle glitch which prevents you from firing this weapon if you've tried to do so underwater. It's a shame that after so many years some of these are still not fixed (and won't be apparently). Also the final boss and conclusion seemed a little bit rushed. Pros:+ Good story+ New areas, weapons, enemies+ Barnacle weapon (personal favourite)+ All the good stuff the original game hadCons:- Annoying glitches- Final boss and ending are rushed- Little to no information about Race XDo you like the original Half-Life? Then you definitely should play Opposing Force. 7.5/10

content:
y 9, 2013
												  This non-inventive game is actually a solid game if you remind yourself you are playing a very linear , half-life based level pack.The levels are a hodge-podge of black-mesa areas / zones. Most fights take place in corridor/small-medium rooms, so keep that shotgun hotkeyed. Mostly you fight aliens, as you are a marine this time around. The enemy is exactly as the alien enemy was in half-life plus a few new baddies (that were borring but not detrimental to the fun).   The level design is linear, but made intereting by having elegantly masked  the progression path with enviornmental puzzles. These puzzles involve shooting explosives to break open a new path, and/or moving crates to reach vents and other areas. The puzzles are rarely stumping/frusterating, yet their sollution gives the illusion of cleverness, which is a satisfying addition to the bad-♥♥♥ feeling you get from the combat.   Music is used very occasionally, often to signify an event that lacks the momentum the sudden and intense music clips would have you expecting. The rest of the sounds are exactly the same as half-life 1. Again this is a half-life level pack, not a sequel or prequel.  As far as story, you're one of the nameless marine grunts gordon kills. Thinks get fubar quick, and pretty soon your alone in black-mesa rushing to meet the evacuating remains of the marines. The story is dictated through the occasional human npcs. The dialogue makes references to the half-life universe and games without really adding to the half-life plot itself. This game can be skipped from the canonical half-life series if you only care about the story.   Its worth the time if you remind yourself to expect a solid level pack , it's just a seamless collection of worth-while (and occasionally excellent) half-life levels.

content:
r 29, 2016
												Expandalone: Half-Life: Opposing ForceDeveloper: Gearbox Software[www.gearboxsoftware.com]Publisher: Valve SoftwareReleased: 1 November, 1999Canon status: Canon unless stated otherwise by Valve SoftwareSetting: 17 May, 2003, Black Mesa Research Facility, New Mexico, U.S.A., EarthSpoiler-free plot summary: You play as Adrian Shephard, a Marine who's been ordered to hunt down the rogue scientist Gordon Freeman, the number one suspect for why aliens are teleporting into the Black Mesa Research Facility. After your osprey was downed by an alien aircraft, you must find your way out of the facility, surviving attacks from aliens, black ops, and hazardous environments.Full review: Half-Life: Opposing Force is the first, and most difficult, of three expandalones for Half-Life developed by Gearbox Software. Opposing Force places you, as its name suggests, on the opposite "team", as it were: the HECU Marines which Freeman was forced to fight through in Half-Life.Opposing Force continues Half-Life's theme of varied environments, puzzles, and a minor story. The gameplay is exactly the same, save for new weapons and enemies. However, what I've found to be far more tedious was the combat. These new enemies can be a mixed variation of too quick, too big, deal too much damage, or have too much health, meaning you usually have low health, low ammo, and die several times, even on the easiest difficulty. I completed about three-quarters of the game before I was forced to use god mode due to how bored I got of dying every few minutes.Do I recommend buying Opposing Force? Yes, but only if you're a Half-Life veteran. For a casual Half-Life player who cares about story/lore first and gameplay second, like myself, you can give this one a miss.

content:
6, 2014
												Wow. Just... wow. At first I went into this game prepared for a shameless cash making title by Gearbox. Well, let's put it this way, it's no Blue Shift. In a good way though. Instead of depending on references to the original to add any form of excitement, direct references are minimal, but awesome (You can murder Gordon Freeman and cause a paradox, teleport to the hazard course, and uncover the secrets of Black Mesa). None of those are even the high points (well maybe the paradox). First off new mechanics: your reticule reacts to being over enemies, and a squad command mechanic to unite with fellow soldiers. Obviously the major new mechanic is the squad command, is it any good? Well... Yes, but also no. What do I mean? It is pretty fun, interesting, and cool. However it is fundamentally flawed. There are three types of fellow soldier, heavy machine gunners that obliterate your enemies quickly, medics that heal you and can fight, and defense engineers that in addition to shooting also take doors down. Well that sounds cool, but they are pretty dumb. They always get in your line of fire, you have to beg to get healed and take down doors (mash 'interact' button like some maniac), and run right into bombs and trip mines. "Davey, hurry up with that door!" "Yes Corporal" *clunk* "Davey, nooooooo! Not that blue laser!" "What?" *boom* Yep that's definitely the worst part of the AI. Absolutely nothing else. Oh, what that elephant in the room, nah ingnore it it's fine. *Sigh* Okay I have to adress the elephant in the room. When you cross into a new chapter they... well they don't do anything. No, really they just stop and stare as you walk away in an almost creepy fashion. So, yeah not so wonderful, but it can still be cool at times. So anything else new? Oh, boy is there new stuff. Sniper rifle, night vision, heavy rifle, desert eagle with laser, pipe wrench, combat knife, barnacle grapple, shock raches, spore launcher, and the displacer cannon. Tons of new enemies that I couldn't even begin to mention to avoid spoilers, but let's just say prepare to run and gun for your life. It's got new maps, but in my opinion, they aren't quite as ingenious as the original maps. Well I have to admit I love the new variety, especially the new weapons. As always what you're supposed to do is often a process of trial and error, but I as an avid Mega Man player have gotten used to that. I guess if I have to be a downer the music isn't quite as good. Overall I'd suggest this game even if you haven't played the original. It's an amazing game on it's own right, not far behind the original. I give it 9.5/10 fallen doors.

												Note: Almost 100% copy-paste from my review of blue shift. Personal rating: 10/10Replayability: LowBudget: I can't name a half-life package deal it isn't a part of. Lenght: A few days to a week. Opposing force is half-life played as a soldier who participates in the assault on Black Mesa. While playing as a different main character, with different levels and a different perspective on the plot, it's essentially the same game, taking place at the same time as the original half-life game. If you liked half-life, you should play this, as it's just as good. Everyone knows half-life, so why should I even bother going into detail about this game? Just consider it additional levels.

content:
2, 2015
												Opposing Force is Half-Life mod made by the late Afghanistan modder Stanley Kubrick.Game starts off with marine zombies fighting each other.  One marine get wrench and beat down other zombies.  He throw wrench into sky which transforms into space ship.  The ship contained Hal who would later marry Glados.You play the role of Private Joker, who is a battle-ready pacifist marine who like taking pictures of dead GI Joes.  This is also one of my hobby so I really feel connected to game.  You can start by doing boot camp with Gomer Pyle and Hartman or dive straight into action.When doing campaign you are either shot down by Viet Cong or Dutchman is pilot.  Not really sure as I am nodding to music.  The music is made of remixed versions of Beethoven music.  This is to remove need for licenses, although one track is based on Singing in the Rain.  To really appreciate the music you need to drink milk plus beforehand.After surviving crash you try to escape but end up with fight against Iranians wearing black onesies.  Most enemy and friend look same in the game.  In fact, all models are based on Peter Sellers.  The Richard Keller model from Decay was further used in Dr. Strangelove or: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bomb.  I only watch film after seeing final word in movie title.Some of the maps can be a maze.  If you get lost it will begin to snow before you freeze to death next to Jack Nicholson.  If you press use button on Jack he say "Never rub another man's rhubarb" before a huge one eye trouser snake try to attack you.  When you kill worm game ends.  Spoiler alert.G-Man trap you on plane and ask for Shephard.  You stand up and say "I am Shephard" but then other marines stand up and say "I am Shephard".  G-Man very confused and not know who real Shephard is.  G-Man say "♥♥♥♥ it, no Shephard in Half-Life 2 then".To play Half-Life 3 you need to enter password "Fidelio".

content:
ry 11, 2014
												Although I would call this more of a spin-off than a mod, this game has won it's awards for good reason. It puts you in exactly the same events as Half Life, sometimes even in some of the same areas as the original game (You even get a peek at Gordon Freeman himself before he enters the one-way portal to Xen).             I really liked this because it had the same style of combat as Half Life, but all the new weapons (Especially the fish) made it even more fun whenever you entered a major combat zone. I would definitely recommend this to any Half Life fan or even any FPS fan, as a must-purchase. Definitely worth the 5 bucks.

ber 1, 2012
												One awesome expansion pack for Half Life, letting you play in the boots of a USMC Marine. Thankfully, you never meet Gordon in-game, or he'd carve you a new haircut, Kurt Cobain style. Gameplay is made much more fun, thanks to the addition of several new weapons, including a portable Barnacle to be used as grappling gun, and a living Grenade Launcher. You may also be in command of a team, and give your otherwise-not-so-bright teammates some basic orders.

er 24, 2015
												Experience a different point of view of the incindent of Black Mesa! In Opposing Force, you play as corporal Adrian Shephard, whose job is to kill Gordon Freeman.I'd say this expansion is better than Blue Shift, because it adds more weapons and enemies, levels are also more fun, in my opinion, as well. As you play, you will sometimes encounter Gordon and even the G-Man. Levels are easier than Half-Life's or at least I think so, because I needed to look up in google much less.Unfortunately, the game sometimes crashes while loading a save file. Other people have experienced crashes on different ocassions.Overall, its probably a good buy if you liked Half-Life. Don't see a reason to purchase it if you haven't played the original first though.

												A great continuation of the half life saga, continuing and expanding on the story of the original half life. content:
r 9, 2015
												[SPOLIERS AHEAD, YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED]This is a very unique game following Cpl. Adrian Shepherd as his team attemps to mute the Black Mesa facility. Failure causes the HECU to port out and go back to base due to invading aliens that are overwhelming them. Shepherd and a few other HECU groups are left behind, and must fight their way out using teamwork, agility, and combat. <Insert story plot n' crap>Eventually, Shepherd finds himself at the underground car lot. The Black Ops are planning to set off a bomb called the "Thermonuclear Device". Shepherd de-activates it but it is re-armed by the mysterious G-Man. Shepherd meets a Security Guard and he tells Shepherd to beware of the Gene Worm that is coming through a portal. Shepherd finally defeats the Gene Worm and is teleported to the G-Man. The G-Man puts Shepherd into a safe place in the corner of the universe where "he can cause no harm". This game very fun to play, but I was ripping my hair out at the voltigores in the underground tunnels.Praise jebebus I made it out. :IMPROVEMENTS:More health scattered around the facilityTake less damageMake the pipe wrench more useful Make Black Ops assassins slowerLess grenade damage

content:
24, 2014
												This is an expansion to the amazing original Half-Life game; this game has you playing as a member of the soldiers you fight in the original game as you battle past aliens alone after losing your fellow soldiers. This game is much shorter than the original Half-Life and isn't quite as good in terms of level design and some combat situations as well as puzzles you are put up against but is still a great experience. It is also amazing that Valve created this expansion as the story of a lone soldier running parallel to the main story; it's really interesting to see the situation from another point of view.13/15 - "Good game but not as good as the original"

content:
r 25, 2016
												I'm assuming most of the reviews are made from nostalgia, this mod starts off strong and quickly ends up being a headache of poor level and monster design. Most of the new weapons are pointless and the tried-and-tested monsters end up replaced with frusting new ones. Grunt enemies are replaced with more assassins who have 100% gun and grenade accuracy and can barely be seen in the dark using your barely-functioning nightvision. Modders were doing much better work at the time with much less resources.

I'd rather replay Episode 1

content:
r 26, 2015
												This review originally written on May 29, 2012 on GameFAQs"Almost as good as the original, don’t miss it!"This is a standalone expansion of Half-Life. I recommend you play this after Blue Shift because I think it's better and I like to save the best for last. The ratings and my feelings of this expansion are gauged in relation to the first Half-Life.STORY: 9/10Here you play one of the marines by the name of Adrian Shephard who enters Black Mesa. You get split up from your team and the game is you progressing along fighting aliens and black ops. The story actually isn't as interesting as Blue Shift, but this has a really cool ending.GRAPHICS: 9/10Again the same graphics as Half-Life, but to be fair this was released soon after so not much time to really improve them. Plus it keeps the same feel so not a big deal.SOUND: 10/10We get all the same sound effects from Half-Life plus more due to all the new content. What few music pieces there are seem to be recycled from the first game though. There are some new voices for the guards and marines which I like.WEAPONS: 10/10Not only do we get nearly all the weapons from Half-Life, but we get more! Notable additions are three new alien weapons. One basically serves as a grappling hook type thing which is pretty interesting but doesn't have much use beyond that. The other two are useful to save ammo for your big guns, but this method isn't needed as you get lots of ammo for everything.ENEMIES: 10/10We see a return of all the enemies from Half-Life but with several more. The new creatures are interesting and unique. A certain type is also very tough and can be tricky to fight especially in a certain area with no light… Unlike Blue Shift we get bosses! There is a boss you must figure out how to get rid of much like a certain one in Half-Life, and a final boss which also requires a bit of cunning.LEVEL DESIGN: 9/10Unfortunately this game is more linear than Half-Life or Blue Shift, but still not bad. There just aren't as many puzzles or alternative ways of getting places. However I must give props to the tutorial which is where you go through advanced training in boot camp. Pretty cool!SQUAD: 9/10Unique to this game is that you get other fellow soldiers who can follow you around and do things. The only ones of note are the engineer who can burn through certain doors, and the medic who can heal you and allies. A few times these guys are used to get past a certain point and you must keep them alive to do their job. They could've done more with them, but at least they tried something new.LENGTH AND REPLAYABILITYThis game is short clocking in at roughly 3 hours or so. This is the game's main flaw. It has a lot of new things like enemies and weapons, but not much time for you to savor it. Regardless it was fun while it lasted and it's still a blast to play with the new weapons and fight the new enemies.FINAL SCORE: 9.5/10Rounded up to 10/10 for GFAQs. This game does what an expansion should do and that's keep the same great gameplay but add more content to play with. This game isn't quite as good as Half-Life mainly due to the length, but that shouldn't stop you from playing this!

content:
r 20, 2014
												We all know Half-Life is the classic. If you enjoyed Half-Life... you may find Opposing Force a little disappointing. In brief; Opposing Force puts you in the shoes of Adrian Shepard... one of the Soldiers sent in to 'clean up' Black Mesa.  Of course things go horribly wrong and you wind up fighting for your survuival and the fate of the world.The Good:* Most of the good things about Half-Life carry over.* New and interesting Enemies* New and interesting Weapons to kill New and Interesting Enemies with.* Explore New Areas of Black MesaAll in all a solid expansion and the idea of having a squad of specialize d soldiers to help you with is always great and leads to some interesting challenges. The Alien X Race also makes for tough antagonists. THe new black ops are also a joy.The Bad* Mundane Area Design.* Bad Lighting* Disjointed STory* GimmickyYeah, the biggest problem here is the lighting. I know Gearbox thought their Light Amp thingie was cool and it admittedly better than the flash light but... it's not practically to have the areas so dark you have to leave it on half the txchuffin time. You will be seeing alot of green in this game.Also the level design ... is dodgey. As in you don't quite feel the interconnection between the areas. In short they feel more like levels and less like actual parts pof a facility in some cases. A minor quibble. Also there are a timed few trial and error sections that will annoy you.Lastly it does feel Gimmickjy. SInce you spend most of your time fighting the allien X creatures... it's actually easy to forget that you're in the same Black Mesa as Gordon freeman and Barney Calhoun. It Might as well have been a different facility all together.Out of the two expansions this feels like the most tangental of them, and the least polished. There's also not much of the story being woven into the background, and it simply lacks the pacing of either Half-Life or Blue Shift.Not that it is a bad game.. it's still quite good but it is a step down rather than hup. Thankffully Half Life raised the bar enough that even a step down is still a high mark.

content:
9, 2016
ProsNew enemies, weapons and mechanics, the game works best when it shows the advantages you have by being a soldier.Shows you a new side of what was considered the enemy team in Half-Life.Cheap price, one of the most content full DLCs I've ever seen taking into account its $/min value.Includes the same multiplayer from Half-Life with an added Capture the Flag gamemode.There are some neat little additions in the animation department, there is a considerable amount of polishment and it shows. One of the alien guns actually have an animation that show the protagonist "petting" the creature. Very nice.During some moments in the game it will interwine with Gordon Freeman's adventure, and you'll be able to see dialogue from the original or even Gordon Freeman himself from a new PoV.There is no Surface Tension-like chapter in this one which is an absolute plus in anything related to Half-Life.The Training Camp chapter is hilarious and a joy to play.ConsMany of the new weapons and enemies are re-hashes of Half-Life weapons and enemies.Some areas feel like a completely different game, pushing my suspension of disbelief that Gordon Freeman never saw the new alien race or the unbelievably differently designed areas of Black Mesa in the original Half-Life (is Black Mesa racist and only let the black guards work in one department?)The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥ing green filter night vision is blinding!The game quickly abandons most of its "soldier" premise after the main team leaves and the rest of the gameplay is mostly a watered down version of Half-Life, with a few new uses of the soldier mechanics here and there.The store page advertises this game like we play as one of the soldiers ordered to murder Gordon Freeman, yet we're never really ordered to do so, as the game already starts close to the "Forget About Freeman" chapter of the original Half-Life. You barely even see Freeman through the game.Like in the original, some of the puzzles are downright impossible without a walkthrough.Like in the original, it's artificially extended, with some badly designed chapters that have no reason to exist in the middle of the actual interesting chapters.The multiplayer barely works most of the time, and is generally dominated by professionals.Disappointing cliffhanger-like ending, that will most likely never get anywhere.OverallIt's still a fun game most of the time but significantly flawed and by the end of it, it's already a chore to play. I recommend only for diehard Half-Life fans since the ending has been confirmed to never get anywhere ever since Half-Life 2 released and it is really more of the artificially extended Half-Life ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This game has VAC and it already includes the HD texture pack from Blue Shift.

												Half-Life: Opposing force is the first and the largest of the three expansions.You play as Corporal Adrian Shepard, he is the closest thing you can get to the DooM guy in Half-Life he isn't as badass and well known as his friend and rival Gordan Freeman he is still awesome.On top of visiting lots of familiar places from the ridge to the lamda teleporter room you also see alot of new places you also get a few new weapons and a set of new enemies and instead of a crowbar, revolver and the two energy weapons you get a wrench, knife (which is like a faster crowbar that does slightly more damage) a teleporter, an LMG, a Race X Shock Roach, a sniper rifle and a Race X Spore Launcher also instead of an HEV (hazardous environment suit) you get a PCV (powered combat vest) which is almost the same with a few differences like a green HUD and NVGs (night vision goggles) instead of a torch which is good in some places but bad in others.IMO this is the game that made Gearbox what they are today.

er 31, 2014
												This game doesn't stand on its own well.  It's severely dated and lacks any real story, and a lot of the choices for this game are poor.  (the alien gun that works as a grappling hook, but only in specific spots - it's otherwise useless, unforgiving difficulty in certain areas, uninspired design, etc.)HAVING SAID ALL OF THAT - do yourself a favor and only play this game after recently finishing Half-Life 1.  All the experience and familiarity from HL will help this game a lot, and fills in what is otherwise a vacant story with the richness of the HL experience.  Otherwise, if you're like me (last played HL1 7+ years ago), this game is incredibly weak and leaves you wondering how there could be so many glowing reviews for such a poor game.  For me, my only previous play-through of Opposing Force was right after I finished HL1, and I loved it.  I can only assume it's because I've forgotten/lost so much of the HL1 experience that this was so uninteresting.

er 17, 2016
												Very dissapointing. The promise of cool new weapons and a new perspective is well enough, but the game spends too much time having the player solve easy but drawn-out puzzles and run around boring enclosed environments rather than fight tooth and nail against aggressive enemies. Eventually it gets there, but by that point you are nearing the end. The new weapons are cool, but you barely get ammo for them and, once again, by the time you do the game is pretty much over. Most of what OP4 does, Half-Life did much better and more creatively. Some mechanics are barely used like the grapple. The trial and error gameplay of Half-Life is still here and somehow worse because now instead of platforming, you are fighting enemies that can quite literally kill you in one hit. Get used to quicksave because you'll be using it here more than in Half-Life. Overall, a very overrated expansion that took Half-Life's elegant design and did a big squirty dump all over it.

ry 5
												SUMMARY STATEMENT:This game is a half-♥♥♥♥♥ attempt to make an alternative plot to half life. Every highlight of the game is just something you saw in the original. The value of this game is nostalgia, nothing more.Every step of the way, you can both see and feel when valve employees said to gearbox developers "oh yeah and its gotta have this part here...  and honestly just model this part after this... you haven't put any of THIS in! Where is THIS?!?!"E.g. they stole the bit where you have to jump across a chasm to reach a ladder, and they ripped off the canyon jumping sequence, and the pit worm (spoiler lol) is modeled after the 3 headed beast in blast pit... you get the idea.You know how the Angry Video Game Nerd talks about video game publishing contractors (e.g. LJN)?That's how i'd describe gearbox while putting out this "gem"Every aspect of gameplay that feels even slightly good is offset completely by remembering how much better it was in the original Half-Life. Valve should NOT let their genius be ripped off by charlatans like gearbox.There are some neat new weapons but for every cool weapon added you have 1 cooler weapon from half-life that didn't happen to make it in and 4 game segments that feel cheesy, like there was minimal effort put into it.It is very easy to imagine this was coded, textured, etc. by about 15 people who spent about 300 man hours between them working on this while being completely focused on something else.Surprisingly, however, the game has fewer glitches than half life. However, it retains the worst glitch of half-life, where you are in a small enclosed space, crouched, and the map changes (and you subsequently get stuck in the floor) meaning that you have to jump a while in the enclosed space, hoping that you happen to be in the air when changing between maps.If you're not out to complete every half life game then this game is not worth itdo not buymultiplayer is abandoned (Half life 1's multiplayer deathmatch isn't, though. Just saying.) so if you want to play that you'll need to arrange for a lan party or something

content:
ry 23
												Boring, bland, mediocre, and utterly pointless. I regret buying it.EDIT: With a push from another steam user, I will now explain why I hate this game in more detail! Wall of text incoming, hold onto your butts.It bored the ♥♥♥♥ out of me because it felt like a lazy re-tread of Half-Life's campaign, down to the shamelessly copying the tentacle fight from the main game (big thing blocks progress, go press two buttons/levers then press this big button to kill it). You even fight spec-ops guys again (which was infuriating the first time, and moreso here). It doubles down on this during its ending when the g-man shows up, and dumps your character into stasis.I found it bland because you play as a marine who comes in shortly before the millitary retreats. Now, if we had taken control of a marine who'd been there from the beginning, and had orders to kill the scientests and purge the facility, then THAT would have been interesting. It would have been a nice twist retreading Gordon's steps and seeing the carnage he left behind, and would have given us more insight into what was going through the soldier's heads as their buddies are massacred en masse by one scientest in a hazmat suit (besides some grafitti and idle chatter in the main game). Honestly, the story of opposing force is a wasted oppertunity (to me anyway).I found it mediocre because the new weapons and mechanics weren't interesting to me. Sure the symbiotic bug was cool, but its a reskin of the hive hand that shoots electricity instead of bees. The teleporting gun was never worth using for its secondary function, because the secret areas RARELY gave anything good. The spore launcher was neat, but obtaining ammo for it was annoying because you need to wait around for its ammo to respawn. The barnacle gun, while initially neat, let me down when I realized how limited its use was: besides a few spots where gunk grew on the walls that you could latch onto, it was utterly useless. Finally, lets talk about the new aliens, and how much I hated fighting them. There's the little guys that swarm you and go down in one hit, the bullet-sponge cyclopses, their weapons that you have to kill after killing them, the tanky ♥♥♥♥ers that you fight in dark narrow corridors, and the final boss. The final boss was the final nail in the coffin for me because, unlike the Nihilanth from the main game, you fight a big dumb worm in what is perhaps the DULLEST fight I've ever had to endure: use turrets to shoot its eyes, then shoot its portal mouth thing. After a few shots, it destroys the catwalk, forcing you to do some platforming to continue shooting it [I didn't bother climbing the rope, I just noclipped between the turrets], while also spawning one of the aforementioned bullet-sponge enemies to drag out the length of the fight. With the Nihilanth, you had to deal with the thing teleporting you, but at least the arena you fought it in was fun. There was nothing fun about Opposing Force. It had no memorable moments besides the ones it ripped off from half-life, and I had to wrack my brain and look at a few videos to remember all the crap I'd forgotten.Finally, this game is utterly pointless. I don't just mean that in the sense that it's existance is pointless, but it contributes NOTHING to the half-life universe. Whatever story or over-arching plot exists here NEVER returns in any form ever again. Your mission was never explained to you or the other schmucks you were brought in with (lazily explaining why the scientests/security force is working with the millitary, who were slaughtering them IN DROVES earlier during the main game), the big explosive that the spec-ops guys brought with them is dealt with stupidly easily, and like I mentioned earlier, at the very end of the game your guy is put into stasis because "hurr durr, that's what happened to Gordon in half-life, so lets do that too!". The greatest example of how pointless this game truly is can be summed up with an encounter early on; you come across a medic, who you need to escort to heal an engineer, who you need to open a door, and once he does, he runs in and is immediatly mowed down by a sentry turret. I could have saved myself 7 minutes of fighting if I'd simply noclipped through the door and kept going. Also, your dumb-as-dirt marine squaddies only follow you for a certain amount of time, and are stopped by invisible lines that they won't cross.And that is why I think that half-life: Opposing Force is a piece of ♥♥♥♥, and why I honestly regret purchasing it.

content:
er 16, 2014
												I thought I'd like Opposing Force, but I did not. It's certainly an interersting concept that appeals to me, the chance to play as a HECU marine during the Black Mesa Incident and be on the side of the "bad guys" is a cool idea in my book, and although Opposing Force opened strong, I felt that as it went on it became progressively weaker. I think that where this game fails the most is in the gameplay. There are way too many weapons that you can carry around in this game (16 in total) and it gets to a point where either you forget to use them or they are redundant. I found myself sticking to the basic, dependable weapons the whole time (shotgun, assault rifle, etc) and there was never really a time when I had to switch to those alien weapons. I should also add that the barnacle gun is pretty much useless except for a couple of pre planned sequences where you have to go across an area using it, so that gun doesnt really see a lot of action which is dissappointing because it would have been cool to grapple up on regular ledges (not organic ones) and get a different view of the battle/tactical advantage. the AI in this game is also rather stupid, your marine buddies who are supposed to tag along with you (and offer you things like health etc.) will either get killed in about 10 seconds or glitch on a wall and stop following you. They're honestly better off dead so that you can take their guns and move along. The story is also pretty much nonexistent. No one bothers to explain where "Race X" comes from (and why Gordon didn't see them in his travels) and the same applies to the Black Ops enemies. They are part of the military, shouldn't they be HELPING you? What reason would they want to kill you for? And that boss battle, geez... what a boring waste of time. Whoever came up with that sorry ♥♥♥ excuse of a boss battle needs to be fired (there's nothing fun about shooting 2 eyes out of a monster). So, overall Opposing Force is an expansion pack that sets out to be as grandiose as the original Half-Life, but fails on its delivery. It's 5 bucks, so at the end of the day it's your choice as to whether or not you think its worth the pick up. But in my opinion, it's not really worth it.

ber 25, 2014
												I don't think I've ever played a game with as much dichotomy in quality as this. The first half of the game is a clear showcase of the practice the developers had making the first two parts of HL1, and is probably the most fun I've had with the series so far. The second half is a tedious parade of gimmicky weapon showcasing at the cost of actually useful resources, and so you spend half your time with your hand stuck up an alien bug's ♥♥♥ and the other half trying to fight off ninjas with half a clip of ammunition for your real guns.I'll admit I've not actually finished this one at the time of writing, as after a while I just didn't have the patience to survive another wave of heavily armored enemies using a space fish's acid loogies and four points of health. Kind of a surprising turnabout considering how strong it started.

content:
2011
												Half-Life Opposing Force sends a shock-wave through my body when playing this enormous of a game. So compelling, mind-boggling puzzles, some big changes from the Half Life Universe. Yet the gameplay stays the same through all of Opposing Force, it's just the minor improvements that make it worth even better than Blue Shift. Playing as Shepard, and being on the bad side of the story-line really put me into a different perspective of how Freeman came to be today. Playing through this once-in-a-lifetime videogame was definetly worthwhile and encouraging, because you get a better sense (and practice) at all the mechanics. That made all of Half-Life ever so great and compelling to tackle upon. Nevertheless the experience was "one Hell of a Fun Ride", Trust me, playing as Shepard when you've beaten every single other games before Half-Life 2 really gets a person in-tune with the story-line.9.33/10GL & HF...

content:
er 29, 2012
												Opposing Force definitely lives up to its name, not only do you get to play as your enemies from Half-Life, but there's also tons and tons of combat! That's not a bad thing either, most of Half-Life was puzzle solving and platforming whereas this is more along the lines of heavy duty survival and combat. The later levels manage to get especially nasty while still finding a nice balance between tactical but still fun. The new weapon ideas that OF offered were hit and miss though, the SAW & Desert Eagle are neat additions whereas the alien guns were iffy and largely boring. Similarly, the barnacle grappling system and the squad system really should've been more refined, they were awesome when they worked right...sadly that just wasn't too often. Although, the new aliens definitely rounded out for a altogether fresh experience, I especially liked how the story that tied into the original so well while avoiding being a total retread. A must play for any fan of Half-Life.Here's to Shepard returning for Half-Life 3!

content:
2014
												Set during the during the events of Half-Life, the Opposing Force expansion pack offers a different perspective as you play the role of one of the soldiers sent in to supress an alien invasion.Opposing Force builds on Half-Life's game mechanics, allowing you to command a small group of soldiers who have different attributes. You have the medic who can heal you and your allies, the engineer who can cut through inaccessable areas and your standard infantry solider who helps you during firefights. The friendly AI is quite rudimentary and you will often witness your allies wandering out into the open and getting cut down by enemies.The enemies you face are similar to those in Half-Life but with a few interesting additions. The aliens you face are more varied as are the weapons you can use to take them down. Opposing Force features some of the most imaginative weapons you can encounter in a first person shooter, from the gun that can teleport you, or your enemies, to destinations unknown to the grenade launcher that is actually a small alien that you feed explosive food to.Opposing Force is a great expansion pack, building on the world established in Half-Life and allowing the player to experience a familiar setting in a different light.

y 20, 2014
												Opposing Force is one of my favourite Half-Life games, and is an amazing addition to the first game. If you played Half-Life 1 and enjoyed it, OpFor delivers an intense, well-paced experience, and adds a lot more to the game. Playing through the Black Mesa Incident as the military is an interesting perspective, and adds to the complex lore of the Half-Life world. It leaves more questions than answers, as Half-Life games tend to do, which is a good thing. OpFor feels very different from the main game, and plays very different too. A lot of new weapons have been added, and although some are just reskinned versions of old weapons, the weapons here feel more militaristic than Gordon Freeman's patched together arsenal of stolen guns and scientific experiments. OpFor offers a lot of new content to Half-Life 1, and is an amazing experience for anyone who enjoyed the first game.

content:
28, 2013
												There are some things you can never play enough. This is one of them.Building on the already genre defining work of Half Life, Opposing Force is perhaps my favourite of HL1.This expansion pack puts you in the jack-boots of cult favourite Adrian Shepard, and kits you up in a uniform that is all too familiar to the Freeman and Half Life players.As one of the military spec ops. marines, you'll see the Black Mesa incident from an entirely new perspective. So even before you exam the gameplay, this is a brilliant piece for fleshing out the story.But the gameplay is actually what makes OF work: It is, in my opinion, of a higher standard than the original game and introduces some fantastic ideas and elemants to the experiance. The player's arsenal increases exponentially, with a dismounted barnacle, electro-laser-xen gun, a teleportation device and the legendary SAW deserving special mention. You'll find no shortage of ways to splatter, maim and exact severe trauma on the interlopers of Xen !The slightly dodgy squad system can be lived with and is very rarely a problem.I recommend this with passion and zeal. A genuinely great piece of work that for me ticks more boxes than the Original Half Life.This is for Half Life fans, story fanatics and for those who may be forgetting just why Half Life is the monolith to the gaming industry that it is.Buy now!

ry 21, 2016
												This is the first of the spin-offs to the highly successful Half Life game, when I say "spin-off" I mean that the game is set in the same universe as the original Half Life game except focused on a different protagnogist. Opposing Force is about a marine named Colporal Adrien Shepard of the HECU Marines of the U.S.A. who is part of a platoon given orders from the government to eliminate all witnesses of the Black Mesa incident. Upon arriving at the outer reaches of the lab facility, the chopper Shepard was on got knock down and after that Shepard got knock out cold and eventually awakes inside the Black Mesa health ward. He soon realizes that the lab facility is over run by hostile aliens and various marines as well as Black Mesa staff members are either dead or horribly mutated. What started out as a simple government cover up is now a survival game for Shepard. With the aid of the last surviving marines and lab staff, Shepard must try to escape from Black Mesa, if he can that is. This was a great attempt to extend the Half Life story by introducing a different character witnessing the events of the Black Mesa incident during the same time frame. A few familiar characters reappear in the game including Barney Calhoun who provided aid to Gordon Freeman and the mysterious G-Man whom you encounter in the last game is present in this game where you get to see what he was doing when not being spotted by Gordon. Similar weapons from the previous game are usable along with newer weapons. While familiar enemies are present along with new enemies who didn't appear in the original game that help make this game less of a carbon copy. The flaws from the first Half Life are also in this game, but highly passable as the game has a great story and plenty of new and familiar locations to explore. The plot contains elements straight out of Full Metal Jacket, James Cameron's Aliens, and the first Predator that creates a military filled game that will satisfy military game fans. If you like Half Life, then you will like this game just as much.

I think it's hard to find a game that inverts the story of the original one, put the player into the role of the antagonist party -at least the human antagonist- and still be a good game. Well, Opposing Force turned out to be a fantastic game, besides some bugs that i encountered through my experience it stood well and took a place in my all time favorites.The story it self, the new protagonist, new allies and foes, new weapons and locations, all of the things mentioned before (and much more) mix and the product is a well paced, action packed story. I won't spoil the plot and things that appear in the game, in the end, it's worth a complete run of the game, to find what new dangers a secrets are found in Black Mesa in this visit in the feet -and boots- of Corporal Shepard.

												The game is really nice, if you don't look at THE STUPID AI OF YOUR TEAMMATES.Seriously, at a point you have to bring a medic into a building to make him heal an engineer that will open the door. First, you'll notice that the medic won't follow you in the building. Second, after PUSHING HIM FOR 5 MINUTES into the building (that's the only way I've managed to do it) you'll be able to make him heal the engi. Now, you have to PUSH THE ENGI FOR FIVE MORE MINUTES out of the building to make him open the door. He'll do it and run into the sentry turret that was right behind it. You destroy the turret, go into a corridor, and find laser mines. I left the crouch button at the wrong time and DIED. I had to do it all again to continue. I didn't.*BIG EDIT* : The AI of teammates works fine if you just go on without bothering with them. I'm guessing the game teleports them where you're not looking, allowing them to get through difficult bits (for bots) of the maps and go where you want them to. This changes my previously negative review into a positive one, as the game has a lot of fun to offer past the point I got stuck at, via new monsters, new weapons, new boss battles, etc !

content:
r 24, 2016
												As time has gone on since I played the first two Half-Life games, I've felt my finger twitch with Half-Life withdrawal. I've wanted to go back to the lack of cutscenes, smooth gameplay, and nailbiting enemies. So, I decided to go back to one of the original expansions for the game made by a young Gearbox Interactive.Oddly enough, it doesn't have the stench of Borderlands covering it, despite the insane new guns added.Half-Life: Opposing Force is a new story taking place during the Black Mesa incident, only now told through the perspective of the marines sent in to capture him, namely one marine named Adrian Shepard, who also has the similar affliction of mute-protagonist that Gordon Freeman has. You go through some of the same events around the crumbling science lab, while fighting a new range of alien enemies with a few new weapons. The game functions just like the original Half-Life. Slippery running, terrible ladders, and tight gunplay all bundled into one old-school PC video game wet dream. The new weapons are pretty effective. My favorite was the equivalent of the BFG from DOOM. No matter what size the enemy you're fighting is, one hit from the gun will immediately destroy them, which will come in handy with all the new alien species that have been thrown in to f*** up your perfectly fine day.All that aside, one problem that comes from Opposing Force is that the story isn't anything new. Sure, there's some new developments that bring further light to the conflict between the marines and their federal higher-ups, but it's just more Half-Life. And, yeah, more Half-Life is fine, but I'd just prefer the story do something a little more new than just follow the same events of Freeman, only through new eyes. It's just a 5 hour long version of Half-Life that wouldn't make sense to anyone that hadn't played the original game first.Opposing Force is still a fun 5-hour long campaign that I felt was worth the money I put into it. If you enjoyed the first Half-Life, you'll still love this expansion. It's just nothing really new or inventive, but as an expasion to an original game... does it really have to be? I'm giving Half-Life: Opposing Force an 8/10. It's a great little experience, but isn't quite as great as it's foundation on which it was constructed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
ber 4, 2016
												A really great expansion to another really great game. Opposing Force shows a different perspective of the events of Half-Life, and it is really great to see why some things happend while playing as Gordon Freeman in Half-Life that occured because of playing as Shepard in Opposing Force. The gameplay and graphics are still the same, but this time I personally feel like the weapons are more unique and fun to use than the weapons that Gordon had. My only complaints are that certain parts of the game can feel a bit repetative and bland, because you have already seen it once before. Also some parts are frustratingly difficult and if you have low health you may get stuck in a loop of death for a while, as there are even less health pickups than in Half-Life, and the final boss is pretty lame in my opinion. Other than that, Opposing Force is a super solid expansion to a super solid game.8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
ber 7, 2016
												In short: the best single player experience of Half-Life, practically no multiplayer available (=two players on one server during a recent check). The voice acting is great, especially "Duke Nukem" i.e. Jon St. Jon as various drill instructors. OF adds a whole slew of new enemies and new weapons to the game, so that the player has many different situations AND weapons options in dealing with them. There is only one Gargantua this time and killing it is completely optional, so there is no longer need to conserve explosives and RPG rockets. Roughly a half of the time you have a squad of multiple soldiers with you much like in The Thing to add some variety. Unfortunately, there are quite a lot of box-movement puzzles and crawling through air ducts again and again and again, so there is some boring content too. The story involves fighting against xenomorphs and stopping Black Ops from blowing up Black Mesa. The level design is really good sans the annoying rope mechanics. There are are some playthroughs of this game in 90 minutes and the multiplayer is dead, so consider carefully if this one is worth your five bucks. If I had to pick only one HL 1 product to buy, it would be this one. The original Half-Life single player does not even compare to this one.

												If you wanna play in order:Half-Life > Half-Life: Opposing Force > Half-Life: Blue ShiftI enjoyed it. Play it if you want to know more about the story and what happened to Black Mesa. Don't get your hopes up for anything as good as Half-Life though. I wasn't really immersed in this as I was it's predecessor. I'm not knocking this game at all. It's good, but it's not "Half-Life" if you know what I mean. Oh and one more gripe. The final boss of this game is pretty lack luster in my opinion. Now if you'll excuse me it's time for me to beat Blue Shift.Edit: I just read a review and felt as though I talked a little too bad about the game. Once again, it's good. That's why I'm reccomending it. The new weapons are great and really do add to the experience. I just said it's not "Half-Life" and I'm standing by it. That could be a good thing though. It's not just some clone trying to attempt to be as good as Half-Life and copy exactly what Valve did. It's a game on it's on showing you neat things and adding more to the original story.

r 29, 2015
												Half-life: Opposing Force is essentially an expanded DLC content wrapped in a standalone package.  In this "game" you take control of the enemy from the original Half-Life.  You are a member of the military force invading Black Mesa Research Facility.  You learn the story of this new character, and through the story of your own, you wind up intertwining with Gordon Freeman during a few of the major plot points of the original title, paralleling him the whole time.This turns out to be a genuinely good addition to the story, but isn't anything vital to the canonical storyline of Half-Life.I'd recommend this title to anyone who thoroughly enjoyed the original game, and wants to expand on its events.

r 11, 2015
												I remember this a few years ago when i decided to pick this up when steam was rolling along. There is a specific instance where when you are about to leave the last part of the Biome level and you have to use the Barnacle weapon to move on to the next area, and half-way through the transistion the game hangs up without fail and the only way to fix this is to get yourself a save point file that happens right after all of this happens.Other than that really, REALLY specific game-breaking error, this has a good singleplayer story expansion pack where you take part in Black Mesa's massive error through the eyes of one of the soldiers that are trying to wipe away any traces left of whatever that one dude Gordon Freeman may or may not have done. Your name is Corporal Shepherd, and you are part of a team that is supposed to kill this Freeman Character. The next events that take place in this expansion pack are what happens near the end of the original Half-Life game, and this is the part where hunting for this freeman character is the least of your worries.I think Gearbox Software did a pretty good job with this one, I mean after all, they did a pretty good job enough to where they started to do their own thing i guess. Bottom line on this game, if you crave for more Half-Life action after completing the original, this is the next stop.

content:
y 4, 2015
												First off, wow. For a splinter game, it can hold it's own pretty well that I feel that I could safely recommend this game. The weapon choice alone pertain to a variation with half of the same weapons from the origin Half-life an other half existing only within this game. The title "Opposing Force" is a bit misleading in that corporal Shepard may work for the military, but his mission objective never quite reached him. The story development does a good job at providing Shepard with a reasonable excuse to not confront Freeman or have to kill any of the scientist. Similar to Blue shift there was a larger focus on the tactical part of the gameplay, yet intriguing puzzle still pop up at regular intervals.  Thankfully there are not too many cases of if-you-mess-this-up-there-is-no-going-back scenerios, but I've bumped into several mess-ups where loading to my last save was in my best interest. I recommend as you play through that you pay some attention to details around you such as a security guard going for a specail discount with a vending machine, and a scientist discovering the wonders of electricity in a way Benjamin Franklin would highly discourage. On another note, I appreciate the detail in adding night vision goggle instead of using a flashlight, but I still prefer the flashlight on the basis that it's easier on my eyes.  Too, you'll soon notice a mysterious set of aliens that never appeared in Half-life before. In fact, I don't think that these alien ever reappear within the Half-life series again. I could be wrong, but for now there's no that I could think of. Importantly, the game provided a satisfying ending. Don't believe me? Then you're welcome to see for yourself. Chances are someone did a thorough walkthrough of the game.

												I enjoyed this one and feel this is the best of the 3. The campaign is shorter then Half-Life but longer then Blue Shift. Compared to Half-Life it actually feels like there is a story to follow, and although there are no hints on what to do. The game doesn't leave you stranded without any clues.The exclusive weapons in this one are fun to use, although the fun ones come quite late in the game.The boss fight in this one is a little underwhelming, and too easy even on the highest difficulty which is really the only negative thing I can say about this game.In conclusion this one is the best of the 3 with an interesting perspective to compliment the original half-life and a interesting weapon selection. The campaign is a proper length just the boss fight feels rushed.

												Half-Life: Opposing Force is an awesome expansion pack to the original Half-Life, but this time from the point of view of a Marine. The storylines of this game run parrallel to the original Half-Life. It is nice to see the different perspective of people in the incident of Black Mesa. The squad experience is fun at times since it adds a little more depth of the situation that there are some struggles that you don't have the expertise to figure out on your own. Some of the iconic moments are still featured with some new exciting moments. This is a must play game to the Half-Life Franchise to get the whole scope of what's happening.

												Half Life Opposing Force is an amazing and enjoyable game introducing new characters and new content to a already awesome game (half life) and has a completely different feeling to it in my opinion than half life. The whole game is worth buying as it increase the thick atmosphere and story of half life. If your a fan of the lore and would enjoy a view of black mesa from a different perspective this is a very good grab and the whole game play and level design is just as good as half life's as well. A must grab for all half life fans!
